abstract: pmc Mater Today Bio Mater Today Bio 3810 mtbio Materials Today Bio 2590-0064 Elsevier PMC12495234 PMC12495234.1 12495234 12495234 10.1016/j.mtbio.2025.102335 S2590-0064(25)00906-8 102335 1 Full Length Article Electroacupuncture at Huatuo-Jiaji acupoints combined with conductive hydrogel synergistically improves bladder and motor functions after spinal cord injury Zhang Qiang a b c d 1 Wei Feng a d 1 Zhang Lulu d 1 Liang Can a Zhuang Yan d Jiang Ning e Weng Wenjie b Qiu Xusheng b Wang Huiru d Chen Yixin chenyixin93@126.com b ⁎ Dai Jianwu jwdai@genetics.ac.cn a d f ⁎⁎ Shen He meggie128@pumc.edu.cn a d ⁎⁎⁎ a b c d e f ⁎ chenyixin93@126.com ⁎⁎ jwdai@genetics.ac.cn ⁎⁎⁎ meggie128@pumc.edu.cn 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. 12 2025 21 9 2025 35 497120 102335 2 7 2025 8 9 2025 20 9 2025 21 09 2025 05 10 2025 05 10 2025 © 2025 The Authors. Published by Elsevier Ltd. 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/). Spinal cord injury (SCI) compromises the electrophysiological properties of tissues and disrupts the electrical transmission pathways, ultimately resulting in motor dysfunction and neurogenic bladder impairment. Therefore, restoration of normal electrophysiological functions in injured spinal cord tissues is crucial for SCI rehabilitation. Electrical stimulation (ES) exhibits therapeutic potential for neurological disorders via neuronal modulation, showing enhanced efficacy in combination with traditional Chinese medicine practices, such as targeted acupuncture. Specifically, acupuncture at Huatuo-Jiaji acupoints, located bilaterally along the vertebral column, exerts neurological regulatory effects. In this study, we developed a dual-modality therapeutic approach combining implantable biomimetic conductive hydrogels for internal ES with electroacupuncture at Huatuo-Jiaji acupoints for external ES to reconstruct the neural electrical microenvironment and synergistically enhance the electrophysiological recovery post-SCI. The engineered conductive hydrogels, fabricated by incorporating carbon nanotubes into photocrosslinkable gelatin matrices, showed dual functionality by facilitating endogenous electrical signal propagation and enhancing the exogenous ES efficacy. This combination therapy significantly attenuated the inflammatory responses and glial scar formation, concurrently promoting axonal regeneration and mitigating demyelination. Functional assessments revealed substantial improvements in both locomotor recovery and neurogenic bladder control in complete spinal cord transection model rats. Mechanistic investigations revealed the downregulation of the Janus kinase–signal transducer and activator of transcription signaling pathway as a key regulator of anti-inflammatory effects of the combination treatment. Overall, our innovative internal–external ES integration strategy offers a promising translational approach for SCI repair by simultaneously enhancing neural regeneration and facilitating functional restoration. Graphical abstract Image 1 Keywords Spinal cord injury Function recovery Electrical stimulation Conductive hydrogel Jiaji acupoints pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement yes pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes 1 Introduction Electrophysiological properties of spinal cord tissues and nerve cells play vital roles in mediating neural signal transmission, thereby governing motor coordination and sensory processing [ 1 2 3 Electrical stimulation (ES) is a promising neuromodulation strategy to restore or modulate the electrical signals post-SCI, thereby creating a favorable environment for neuronal regeneration and functional recovery. Internal and external ES are classified based on their action modes. The former utilizes electroconductive biomaterials to engineer biomimetic three-dimensional scaffolds replicating the native extracellular matrix architecture and providing topographical and electrotactic guidance for neural regeneration. These engineered constructs not only amplify endogenous bioelectrical signaling but also orchestrate cellular responses via spatiotemporally controlled activation of neurons and glia, culminating in accelerated axonal regrowth and circuit formation [ 4 5 External ES improves local blood circulation and metabolic activity, regulates neurotransmitter release, and effectively suppresses inflammatory responses and glial scar formation, thereby promoting neural circuit remodeling and restoring the physiological functions. However, targeting and systematic regulation capacities of ES require improvement. Electroacupuncture (EA) stimulation, synergistic integration of millennia-old acupuncture and modern bioelectronic principles, offers anatomical precision via meridian-specific stimulation. Notably, 50 Hz EA stimulation exerts neuroprotective effects predominantly via nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2-mediated oxidative stress suppression and lysosomal–autophagic flux potentiation in SCI model rats [ 6 7 [8] [9] [10] 11 12 13 To enhance the therapeutic accuracy and effectiveness of ES, we developed an internal and external combination ES strategy by combining conductive hydrogel implantation at the defect site and EA stimulation at the Jiaji acupoints to synergistically reconstruct the neural electrical microenvironments at the injured site, thereby promoting SCI repair. The T8 and T10 Huatuo-Jiaji acupoints were selected based on their neuroanatomical relationship to the T9 injury site and principles of traditional Chinese medicine (TCM). Neuroanatomically, the Jiaji acupoints are located adjacent to the intervertebral foramina, where spinal nerves emerge to innervate both motor and sensory pathways relevant to the T9 lesion level and EA on Jiaji points has been proved can stimulate the appropriate posterior ramus of the spinal nerve originating from the lower vertebrae [ 14 15 16 17 18 19 Fig. 1 Fig. 1 Electroacupuncture (EA) at the Jiaji acupoints combined with conductive hydrogel application synergistically enhances spinal cord injury (SCI) repair by promoting endogenous neural stem cell (NSC) migration and differentiation and axonal growth, regulating inflammatory responses, and suppressing scar formation. Fig. 1 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Conductive hydrogel synthesis and characterization The Gl-C hydrogels were prepared as previously described [ 5 Morphologies, conductivities, and mechanical properties of the Gl-C hydrogels were examined using a scanning electron microscope (Quanta 400 FEG; FEI Company, Oregon, USA), electrochemical workstation (CHI660D; Chenhua Instrument Co., LTD, Shanghai, China), and rheometer (AR2000 MTS; TA Instruments, New Castle, Delaware, USA), respectively. Their biodegradation properties were evaluated as previously described [ 5 2.2 NSC proliferation and differentiation assays NSCs were extracted and cultured as previously described [ 20 21 22 Wnt9a Wnt7a Ngn2 Tables S1 and S2 2.3 Surgical procedure and combined Gl-C hydrogel implantation and EA stimulation at Jiaji acupoints 140 female Sprague–Dawley rats (8–10 weeks old; 200–220 g) were purchased from Shanghai Slaughter Laboratory Animal Co. (China). All animal experiments adhered to the National Institutes of Health Guidelines for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals and were approved by the Animal Care and Use Committee of the Suzhou Institute of Nano-Tech and Nano-Bionics, Chinese Academy of Sciences (approval number: SINANO/EC/2023-YFC2412502). Complete transection SCI model rats were established as previously described [ 23 24 Rats in the Gl + EA and Gl-C + EA groups were stimulated via EA at the Jiaji acupoints for 30 min per week from day 7 post-surgery. Two sets of acupuncture needles (0.25 mm × 40 mm; Research Taihe; Changchun Aikang Medical Equipment Co., Ltd., China) were vertically inserted into the Jiaji acupoints located adjacent to the 8th and 10th thoracic vertebrae ( Fig. 1 2.4 Electric field detection in SCI rats Neurostim-8 probe (Nanjing Changxiang Medical Technology Co., Ltd., China) was used to record the electrophysiological signals in the injured and treated spinal cord, and bladder tissues during applying EA at the Jiaji acupoints. Recordings from each SCI rat were repeated at least three times, and the waveform morphology consistency was verified in trials. 2.5 Histological analyses Ten day and eight weeks after treatment, spinal cord samples were harvested as previously described [ 25 Table S2 2.6 Evaluation of functional restoration Locomotor function recovery was evaluated using the Basso–Beattie–Bresnahan (BBB) scale [ 26 26 27 2.7 Transcriptome sequencing analysis After eight weeks of treatment, spinal cord tissue samples were collected from the injured site, spanning 8 mm rostral and caudal to the lesion site. RNA-seq was performed to elucidate the potential molecular mechanisms. Spinal cord samples of the Gl-C and Gl-C + EA groups were preserved using the TRIzol Reagent (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Transcriptome sequencing analysis was performed by OE Biotech Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). RNA was extracted using standard methods, and quality control was performed using the NanoDrop 2000 spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific, USA). RNA integrity was assessed with the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA). Subsequently, libraries were constructed using the VAHTS Universal V6 RNA-seq Library Prep Kit, and sequenced on the Illumina NovaSeq 6000 platform, generating 150 bp paired-end reads. Gene expression levels were normalized to fragments per kilobase of transcript per million mapped reads (FPKM) using Cufflinks, while raw read counts were quantified with HTSeq-count. Differential expression analysis was conducted using the DESeq2 package, applying a significance threshold of p < 0.05 to identify statistically significant genes. To visualize expression profiles, hierarchical clustering was applied to the differentially expressed genes. Furthermore, functional enrichment analyses, including Gene Ontology (GO) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) pathways, were carried out in R using a hypergeometric distribution-based approach. 2.8 Statistical analyses Data are represented as the mean ± standard deviation. All results were statistically analyzed via independent t p p p p 3 Results 3.1 Conductive hydrogels regulate the NSC fate Physicochemical properties of the conductive Gl-based hydrogels modified with varying CNT concentrations were characterized. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis revealed that the Gl-C hydrogels exhibited an interpenetrating porous structure (pore size: 40–120 μm; Fig. 2 Fig. S1A–D Fig. 2 Fig. 2 Fig. 2 Fig. 2 Characterization of Gl-C hydrogels. p Fig. 2 Biocompatibility assays confirmed the non-cytotoxicity of the Gl-C20/40/80 scaffolds to NSCs ( Fig. S1E + Fig. 3 + Ngn2 Wnt7a Wnt9a Fig. 3 Fig. 3 Effects of Gl-C hydrogels on NSC migration and differentiation. + + + + p p p p Ngn2 Wnt7a Wnt9a p p p + + p Fig. 3 Next, we investigated the effects of Gl-C hydrogels on endogenous NSC migration and neurogenesis using complete transection SCI rat model. Nestin, an NSC marker, was used to detect the SCI-activated endogenous NSCs, which play a critical role in replacing the lost neural cells via proliferation and differentiation. Both immunofluorescence imaging and quantitative analysis revealed that the fluorescence intensity of nestin-positive cells in the lesion area was significantly higher in the hydrogel transplantation groups than in the SCI group ten days post-surgery ( Fig. 3 + Fig. 3 + Fig. 3 3.2 EA stimulation enhances the conductive hydrogel-mediated electrical conduction at the spinal cord and bladder Electrophysiological assessments were conducted to evaluate the spinal cord and bladder voltages by recording the electrical signals at both sites during EA treatment seven days post-surgery ( Fig. 4 Fig. S2 p p Fig. 4 28 p p Fig. 4 Fig. 4 Amplitude measurements in the spinal cord and bladder with EA treatment at seven days post-surgery. p p Fig. 4 3.3 EA stimulation improves conductive hydrogel-mediated neural regeneration After eight weeks of treatment with the conductive hydrogels and EA stimulation, major organs, including the heart, liver, spleen, lungs, and kidneys, were harvested from the rats, and hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining was performed to assess inflammation. As shown in Fig. S3–S6 Fig. S7 Conductive hydrogels were implanted into the spinal cords with complete defects, and spinal cord regeneration was evaluated eight weeks post-surgery. In the SCI, Gl, and Gl + EA groups, spinal cord defects remained clearly visible with distinct boundaries, indicating limited regeneration. In contrast, Gl-C40 group showed no obvious defects and smooth surface morphology at the injury site. Gl-C40 + EA group exhibited more extensive tissue regeneration in the defect area than the scaffold-only group with blurred boundary lines, suggesting improved tissue integration and repair ( Fig. 5 Fig. 5 EA stimulation at the Jiaji points significantly enhances the effects of the conductive hydrogels on axon regeneration and demyelination suppression eight weeks post-surgery. + p p p p p p Fig. 5 Neurofilament (NF) staining was performed to histologically evaluate axonal regeneration. As shown in Fig. 5 Fig. 5 Fig. 5 3.4 Combined EA stimulation and Gl-C40 hydrogel application suppresses inflammation and scar formation Inflammation typically induces secondary damage and impedes neural recovery following SCI. Histological analysis revealed that inflammatory cell infiltration, tissue edema, and fibrosis at the center of the spinal cord lesion were most severe in the SCI group but showed progressive attenuation in the Gl, Gl-C40, and Gl + EA groups, with no detectable pathological features observed in the Gl-C40 + EA group ( Fig. 6 Fig. S8 Fig. 6 EA enhances the anti-inflammatory and anti-scarring effects of the Gl-C40 hydrogel. + p p p Fig. 6 Formation of a chronic glial scar, a physical barrier to axonal regrowth [ 29 + + Fig. 6 p 3.5 Combination treatment synergistically improves the locomotor and bladder functions Functional motor recovery in rats was systematically evaluated via footprint analysis, BBB locomotor rating, and inclined plane testing. In the SCI group, hindlimb muscle strength was severely compromised, with a complete loss of anti-gravity function. Although rats in the Gl group demonstrated resistance movement at the distal joints, their overall muscle strength remained suboptimal. Moderate improvements were observed in the Gl-C40 and Gl + EA groups, with both the proximal and distal joints exhibiting resistance capacity. Remarkably, Gl-C40 + EA group showed intermittent weight-bearing locomotion in the hindlimbs accompanied by coordinated forelimb movement ( Fig. 7 Fig. 7 Fig. 7 Fig. 7 EA combined with Gl-C40 hydrogel synergistically promotes motor and bladder function recovery. p p p p p p Fig. 7 Normal micturition requires precise coordination between bladder detrusor contraction and urethral sphincter relaxation mediated by the supraspinal neural circuits [ 30 31 Fig. 7 Fig. 7 Fig. S9A and B Fig. 7 Fig. S9C–F 3.6 Transcriptomic characteristics of the EA and conductive hydrogel combination treatment in SCI repair To investigate the potential therapeutic SCI repair mechanisms of the combined treatment, we performed RNA-seq analysis of the injured spinal cord tissues eight weeks post-treatment. Differential gene expression analysis revealed 850 significantly altered genes in the Gl-C40 + EA group compared to those in the Gl-C40 group (log 2 Fig. 8 Fig. 8 EA combined with conductive hydrogel scaffold reduces the pro-inflammation and promotes nerve regeneration. Il13ra2 Il23a Lif p p Fig. 8 Multimodal functional analysis combining KEGG pathway enrichment and gene set enrichment analysis revealed the dual effects of the combined treatment on the neural and immune systems. KEGG analysis indicated that the downregulated genes were predominantly associated with immune response pathways (e.g., Th17 differentiation) and pathological processes, whereas the upregulated genes were clustered in neural circuit remodeling pathways, including neuroactive ligand–receptor interactions, synaptic vesicle cycling, and GABAergic/glutamatergic synapse regulation pathways ( Fig. 8B– Fig. 8 Fig. 8 In addition to promoting neuroregeneration, Gl-C40 + EA regimen significantly attenuated secondary injuries via immune–inflammatory pathway regulation. Key inflammatory mediators ( Il13ra2 Il23a Lif 2 Fig. 8 Fig. 8 Fig. S10 Fig. S11 Fig. 8 These multi-omics findings establish a mechanistic framework wherein Gl-C40 + EA combination therapy downregulates the immune–inflammatory cascades to mitigate secondary damage and upregulates neural plasticity programs via 1) synaptogenesis enhancement by neuroactive ligand–receptor systems, 2) axon regeneration potentiation via MAPK/BNDF–TrkB signaling, and 3) GABAergic circuit stabilization to prevent pathological hyperexcitability. This dual-axis regulation creates a permissive microenvironment for structural and functional neural recovery. Through comprehensive transcriptomic deconvolution, we demonstrated that combined Gl-C40 hydrogel and Jiaji-EA stimulation promoted synergistic neural recovery via immunomodulation and neural restoration. Our findings provide a rationale for the development of novel bioelectronic hydrogel therapies targeting neural repair and immune modulation for SCI management. 4 Discussion Despite concerns regarding their biocompatibility, carbon-based nanoparticles show promise for neural tissue engineering. In this study, CNTs were functionalized to improve their dispersibility and reduce cytotoxicity, as shown in our previous in vitro and in vivo tests [ 5 32 The naive spinal cord tissue exhibits electrical conductivity as endogenous bioelectrical signals are essential for maintaining the neuronal functions and facilitating axonal growth [ 33 34 2+ 35 5 36 37 38 Conductive hydrogel combined with ES promotes NSC differentiation into neurons while inhibiting astrocyte proliferation [ 39 6 40 41 42 43 44 The pro-inflammatory microenvironment post-SCI exacerbates scarring and impedes axonal regeneration. Our study demonstrated that EA at the Jiaji acupoints combined with conductive hydrogel markedly reduced neuroinflammation. Transcriptome analysis further revealed the downregulation of JAK/STAT signaling, a key macrophage/microglial polarization and inflammatory response regulator. Western blot analysis of the p-JAK2 and p-STAT3 will be carried out in future study. In addition, a recent study has proven that in a construction of rat SCI model, the electroacupuncture at Jiaji acupoints regulated JAK-STAT signaling pathway. The western blot results showed that the expression levels of p-JAK2 and p-STAT3 decreased in the Jiaji EA group compared to those in the SCI group, indicating the inhibition of the activation of the JAK2/STAT3 pathway [ 45 46 47 48 5 Conclusion In summary, a Gl-C40 hydrogel was synthesized and applied with EA stimulation at the Jiaji acupoints to facilitate tissue regeneration following SCI by establishing a continuous conductive circuit within the damaged spinal cord of rats. Combined application of the Gl-C40 hydrogel and EA treatment significantly modulated the inflammatory responses, enhanced endogenous neural regeneration, promoted axonal growth and myelination, ameliorated neurogenic bladder dysfunction by reconstructing the neural circuits, inhibited bladder fibrosis, and improved the locomotor function recovery. These effects were potentially mediated by the EA-induced upregulation of neural plasticity-related pathways and inhibition of the JAK/STAT signaling pathway. Collectively, our results suggest that maintaining a permissive biophysical microenvironment with electroactive stimulation is crucial for SCI repair. This innovative combinatorial approach integrating EA stimulation at the Jiaji acupoints with conductive hydrogel provides a novel avenue to enhance central nervous system regeneration for neural tissue engineering.
